The title could be "The design changes for phosphor-state-manager to support complete power control"

+1 also "capture multi-host power good monitoring support ", "addition of sub-chassis power control support" ,sled cycle support as sub topics in commit message which are major design proposals in the document
This paragraph is not clear. Can you summarise mainly what this design is trying to introduce or achieve for the existing problem.
There are additional requests like graceful reboot ,graceful warm reboot, force warm reboot which are supported by host state manager please add them too.
did you mean "supported power control request types under host state manager"
did you mean chassis state manager requests
can you give any more detail on this under background and references section along with any reference to the design discussion with the community.
can you explain more detail on this under background and references section

since we have already discussed about the support details in previous sections,
please capture only the specific requirement which needs to be introduced.
example : "add sub-chassis object path for each host /xyz/openbmc_project/state/chassis_systemX"

can you reword it to make it clear? also it will be useful which part the phosphor state manager these proposed changes will be done like change needs to be done under phosphor-chassis-state-manager or phosphor-host-state-manager
this interface is already part of PDI right. we are only introducing new dbus object path with the same interface? can you clarify?
as you mentioned here is right, I have updated.
can you explain what will be the difference between sub-chassis(/xyz/openbmc_project/state/chassis_systemN) power control requests and chassis control(/xyz/openbmc_project/state/chassis1) requests
can you explain more on this like the dbus object paths and interfaces involved with this change?
can you specify the relevant dbus object path and interfaces which will be used part of this feature?

how this sub-chassis power control feature will be handled for the platforms without this sub-chassis? for the platforms not supporting the sub chassis should this feature can be disabled and should not affect their normal operation. can you explain how it cane be handled ?
Testing part needs to be updated with more info/test cases/

This starts out with "the plan". It should start with the next paragraph, describing the problem (x86-power-control assumes GPIO's for power control and that is not suitable for your system design, phosphor-state-manager seems like the better option with some enhancements detailed in this design doc).
nit: one space between . and start of next sentence.
This part of sentence doesn't make sense.
nit: Capitalize (or change the preceding . to a ,)
nit: Multiple instances in this doc of exceeding 80 char limit
Previous bullets listed the problem, but this seems to be more of a "Add support" type statement.

I'm not sure about the use of "slot" in this document. My understanding of the chassis_systemX object is it represents the power domain for a complete "system" within a system. So why not obmc-chassis-system-poweron@{}.target?

Right now, you start phosphor-chassis-state-manager with a parameter, --chassis, to indicate the chassis instance. Will this have a 1x1 mapping to chassis_systemX? Or how will the chassis-state-manager application know which instance of chassis_systemX to create?

This title is way too long.

"design: phosphor-state-manager: support complete power control" ?

I don't know what "support complete power control" means.  Please give a 2-4 word description of what is incomplete about the current implementation (and thus what you are adding) instead of a vague phrase like this.

"addition power control targets"?

I like this document as a way to discuss the proposed changes to PSM, but I'm not sure it makes much sense as a standalone design doc. I think once this is "approved", it may make more sense to move its content into the existing README.md within PSM.

Seems it may be time to start pushing up some patches to gerrit to get the ball rolling.
Didn't you already write this 4 lines earlier?

markdown doesn't normally allow indented code-escapes like this.

Please look at this document in a markdown render and make sure it looks decent.  I suspect there are many changes to be made throughout.

Here is a rendering of the current commit:
https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/e0145090b95c25f4138972a7a391675c5672ab6b/designs/phosphor-state-manager-power-ctrl-enhancement.md

I don't think Example is part of any YAML here.

What does "Object path:" refer to?

it is referred to as the full power cycle of the entire system(sled cycle).

https://lists.ozlabs.org/pipermail/openbmc/2020-October/023540.html

Hi all gentle reminder,
please review the patch and provide your suggestions.
Thanks

Would suggest looking at https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/58422, https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-state-manager/+/58331 and https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/56806 for implementation of much of this functionality on the greatlakes platform to see if it can be reused.

individual slot?

In line 21, slot is used, here host is used.

Slot and host are used inconsistently.  When referring to a Twinlake system, 'slot' should be used.  When referring to code, it would be best if 'host' was used to align with the way code refers to a system.
Remove this as the sentence already indicates 'no support for'.
Is this a host or chassis or both?
Currently, the chassis on/off is supported.  It is proposed...

If I'm reading this sentence, I think it means the following:

Based on POST completing, add support for OS (Operating System) state change.
Host on off and reboot exist. Here slot meants to be a 12V slot on, off, and reboot.
Host on off and reboot exist. Here slot meants to be a 12V slot on, off, and reboot.
In addition, the targeted platform needs to add support to handle chassis power cycle.
This needs to be a sentence and not a fragment.
are the same: on, off and power cycle.  The change needed is to implement a different object path under phosphor-chassis-state-manager.

run-on sentence.  

A change to read the power good status for each sub-chassis and host to determine the initial power status is needed.
Code needs to be added in phosphor-state-manager to capture the OS state change.

Is this referring to the multi-host architecture of Greatlake?

We get final architecture shared by Patrick and Garnermic for multi-host are as follow: 
1. /xyz/openbmc_project/state/Host{1 to N} corresponds to soft host 1 to N. It includes the poweron/off/softoff/cycle/shutdown ..etc.
2. /xyz/openbmc_project/state/Chassis{1 to N} corresponds to slot 1 to N. It includes power on/off/cycle.
3. /xyz/openbmc_project/state/Chassis0 corresponds to entire machine. It includes power(sled) cycle.

As architected above,Maybe we don't need subsystems path to represent slots,and add sled-cycle to all chassis object paths.

Is this referring to the multi-host architecture of Greatlake? ->Yes
It looks like there is some discussion going on with Patrck and Garner. I'm not
aware of that, if possible please update this patch set based on your final architecture.
Our code is under review. If we confirm that the code does not require changes, we will update the design docs.
